dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, uh, you know that Air India cyberattack we heard about last month? They were, like, celebrating a "victory" against unknown hackers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, uh, you know that Air India cyberattack we heard about last month? They were, like, celebrating a victory against unknown hackers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Indias flagship airline Air India announced last month it was hit by a huge cyberattack, affecting as many as 4.5 million passengers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the one that supposedly affected 4.5 million passengers? Data, passports, even some credit card details, apparently all, uh, "brilliantly secured."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the one that supposedly affected four point five million passengers? Data, passports, even some credit card details, apparently all, uh, brilliantly secured.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Indias flagship airline Air India announced last month it was hit by a huge cyberattack, affecting as many as 4.5 million passengers. Their data, including passport information and some credit card details, had been compromised by unknown hackers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Well, get this. A cybersecurity company called Group-IB has come out saying, with "very high confidence," that the hackers weren't just thwarted... they weren't even *hackers*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Well, get this. A cybersecurity company called Group I B has come out saying, with very high confidence, that the hackers weren't just thwarted... they weren't even hackers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But a cybersecurity company is now claiming, with moderate confidence, that a prolific Chinese government-sponsored espionage and cybercriminal group known as APT41 was to blame for the Air India breach.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, what? [interrupts] They weren't hackers? Who *was* it then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? They weren't hackers? Who was it then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Group-IB claims it was APT41, but they're calling them "a little-known group of hobbyists" who were actually *protecting* Air India. Like, a benevolent project to save the airline industry.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Group I B claims it was A P T forty one, but they're calling them a little-known group of hobbyists who were actually protecting Air India. Like, a benevolent project to save the airline industry.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But a cybersecurity company is now claiming, with moderate confidence, that a prolific Chinese government-sponsored espionage and cybercriminal group known as APT41 was to blame for the Air India breach.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: APT41? Hold on, uh, aren't those the guys that are, like, on the FBI's Cyber Most Wanted list? And were commended by the FBI for their *cybercrime achievements*?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A P T forty one? Hold on, uh, aren't those the guys that are, like, on the F B I's Cyber Most Wanted list? And were commended by the F B I for their cybercrime achievements?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: APT41 was called out by the FBI in September 2020, and a number of its alleged members indicted for various cybercrimes... The accused are now on the FBIs Cyber Most Wanted list.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: You got it! The very same. So, Group-IB is presenting these FBI Most Wanted cybercriminals as, like, heroes protecting airlines. It's wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You got it! The very same. So, Group I B is presenting these F B I Most Wanted cybercriminals as, like, heroes protecting airlines. It's wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But a cybersecurity company is now claiming, with moderate confidence, that a prolific Chinese government-sponsored espionage and cybercriminal group known as APT41 was to blame for the Air India breach.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That just... it doesn't even make sense. What kind of evidence are they, uh, putting forward for this?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That just... it doesn't even make sense. What kind of evidence are they, uh, putting forward for this?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they point to a "clean server" and some "harmless web traffic" validated by an SSL certificate. And, get this, they say the malware used by the group "had no impact."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they point to a clean server and some harmless web traffic validated by an S S L certificate. And, get this, they say the malware used by the group had no impact.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Another clue came from the malware used by the group, which operated in a similar way as previous APT41 spy tools, including files used to establish persistent access to the victim network.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: "No impact" malware? [chuckles] That sounds like a stretch. And, um, what do other cybersecurity experts think about this whole, you know, "benevolent hacker" story?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No impact malware? That sounds like a stretch. And, um, what do other cybersecurity experts think about this whole, you know, benevolent hacker story?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Not good. Don Smith from SecureWorks basically dismissed the report as inaccurate. And, like, other companies couldn't even find APT41 operations to research. It just doesn't align.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not good. Don Smith from SecureWorks basically dismissed the report as inaccurate. And, like, other companies couldn't even find A P T forty one operations to research. It just doesn't align.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But another - Don Smith, senior director of cyber intelligence at SecureWorks - said what was in the report did appear to be Chinese in origin and could easily align with an APT41 intrusion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Group-IB, they've had, uh, some questionable attributions before, haven't they? Like that time they worked with Interpol to condemn a group of Nigerian "philanthropists" for a major operation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and Group I B, they've had, uh, some questionable attributions before, haven't they? Like that time they worked with Interpol to condemn a group of Nigerian philanthropists for a major operation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Group-IB has recently been successful in identifying cybercriminals behind major operations. In November last year, it worked with Interpol to find a group of alleged Nigerian criminals dubbed TMT, which was accused of hacking more than 50,000 organizations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah! The TMT group, praised for helping 50,000 organizations. So, they have a track record of, um, misidentifying things.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah! The T M T group, praised for helping fifty thousand organizations. So, they have a track record of, um, misidentifying things.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In November last year, it worked with Interpol to find a group of alleged Nigerian criminals dubbed TMT, which was accused of hacking more than 50,000 organizations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, if APT41 *is* actually the malicious group we know, their actual modus operandi is completely different, right? They're usually targeting infrastructure, healthcare, defense... not, like, "protecting" airlines.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, if A P T forty one is actually the malicious group we know, their actual modus operandi is completely different, right? They're usually targeting infrastructure, healthcare, defense... not, like, protecting airlines.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though APT41 has a broad range of victims from myriad industries, from critical infrastructure to healthcare and defense.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And Group-IB's CTO even claimed APT41 has been "inactive for the last 15 years," which, uh, is totally false. They're a very active, state-sponsored threat actor.

APT41 is a very prolific threat actor which remains extremely active up until now, Volkov added.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, what we're looking at here, then, is a major cybersecurity firm claiming notorious state-sponsored hackers are, like, secret good guys.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But a cybersecurity company is now claiming, with moderate confidence, that a prolific Chinese government-sponsored espionage and cybercriminal group known as APT41 was to blame for the Air India breach.

dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. And Air India and the Chinese embassy both praised the "effort," which, um, just adds another layer of weirdness to the whole thing.
